body:
> The terminfo database provided with ncurses 6.1 defines a couple of "features" related to this: xterm+direct, xterm+direct2 and xterm+indirect.

Note the `+` instead of `-`. This convention is used to indicate a "feature" rather than a complete terminfo entry (like _xterm-direct_).

Some more info can be found in the terminfo sources: http://www.invisible-island.net/ncurses/terminfo.src.html#tic-xterm_direct2

> \# Emacs 26.1 and later support direct color mode in terminals, using a
> \# combination of user-defined capabilities and ncurses-dependent function
> \# calls.  We will not include that here.
> \# 
> \# Here is a first revision, which (disregarding the reuse of colors 1-7 which
> \# is of interest only to the numerically illiterate), is compatible with other
> \# terminal descriptions written for curses.  It relies upon the extended range
> \# for numeric capabilities provided in ncurses 6.1:
> xterm+direct2|xterm with direct-color indexing,

and

> \# That in turn had a problem: in the original patch submitted for KDE konsole
> \# in 2006, the submitter and the developer alike overlooked a "color space
> \# identifier" parameter.  This version provides for that parameter:
> xterm+direct|xterm with direct-color indexing,

and

> \# Meanwhile, in KDE #107487, the patch submitter and the developer both saw
> \# that xterm's original implementation should have used colons for the
> \# subparameter separators, but chose not to correct this in konsole.  As of
> \# late 2017, konsole still accepts only the nonstandard semicolon delimiters.
> xterm+indirect|xterm with direct-color indexing (old),

Wow, thank you for the incredibly detailed report here. The suggestions here sound like the right path forward (including terminfo changes). I think we can safely skip the mixed version of true color parsing, though.

I noted that the current alacritty.info sets **ritm** and **sitm**. Other than that, it is identical to xterm. ~I have no idea which is more correct; keep them, or remove them.~

I removed them in my replacement alacritty.info and haven't noticed any issues. ~But that doesn't mean it's the correct thing to do :)~

If they aren't needed, then alacritty (and alacritty-256color) would be identical to xterm and xterm-256color. In this case, alacritty.info could be completely removed **after** the colon-separated 24-bit escape sequence has been implemented, since then you could use xterm-direct (but there is no xterm-indirect, hence the requirement of alacritty-direct for now).

**edit**
xterm already defines ritm/sitm, so they aren't necessary in alacritty.info.

So, **sitm** is _enter italic mode_ and **ritm** is _leave italic mode_. I assume they are set to what they are because that's how urxvt does it?

I've read e.g. https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1455 that brings up the xterm vs urxvt differences, and would just like to add that the terminfo is also affected by this; if alacritty aims to be urxvt compatible, the default TERM value should be urxvt, not xterm (or, if using the alacritty specific terminfo entry, it should be based on the urxvt one, not xterm).
I wasn't aware of alacritty trying to always be urxvt compatible. See [this](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/pull/1351#issuecomment-395231088) comment I made on an unrelated issue.

@nixpulvis I'm not sure what alacritty tries to be, and I hope it didn't sound like I was saying it is trying to be urxvt compatible.

I was merely trying to understand why alacritty.info was based off of xterm, but then defined ritm/sitm explicitly. Since I had seen urxvt being mentioned as _one_ terminal whose behavior alacritty's was compared to, I suggested that might be the reason.

What I _did_ do was check how urxvt defined it's ritm/sitm, and found that they matched alacritty's. Hence the above conclusion/suggestion.

What I **should** have done, was to _also_ check the xterm terminfo entry. If I had done that, I would have seen that it **also** sets ritm/sitm to the exact same values. Hence the explicit ritm/sitm in alacritty.info is unnecessary.

> Hence the explicit ritm/sitm in alacritty.info is unnecessary.

Part of why we include them is that some older xterm.info entries don't include them. For instance, Ubuntu 14.04 didn't but 16.04 does.

@jwilm ah, and that brings up backward compatibility; ncurses 6.1 is relatively new, and I guess some distros will take their time to get it. Making it difficult (maybe) to update alacritty.info to use e.g. xterm-indirect.
@dnkl what do you think about having a complete terminfo definition for Alacritty that doesn't rely on system xterm terminfo entries?

@jwilm I think that's a good idea. Even if you try to be xterm compatible, there's always going to be cases when you aren't. Using your own terminfo allows you to more easily compensate for that. 

Long answer:

Relying on the system's xterm terminfo entries means you don't really know what you're getting. A new ncurses release may bring in changes that are in conflict with alacritty's implementation, and you would probably not notice it.

Also, by using your own terminfo, you can more precisely describe alacritty. You could, in theory, make xterm incompatible changes and, assuming you update the terminfo data, still work. At least with well behaving applications.

You could probably connect the terminfo description to at least some of the key bindings and the escape sequences they generate. I.e. generate either one of them from the other.

Looking at other projects, there appear to be different views on what's "correct".

The konsole maintainer has stated (https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=145977) that he prefers users to set `TERM=xterm(-256color)`, because he wants konsole to be 100% xterm compatible, and if something doesn't work the same way, it's a konsole bug.

Both st and urxvt on the other hand, have their own (complete) terminfo definitions.

I think the advantages of **not** relying on (unknown) system definitions outweigh any potential downsides. At least initially, I would model the definition after xterm's; split it up into the same "features" and combine them into the final `alacritty` definition in the same way xterm's terminfo is done.

That way, it's fairly easy to pull in "upstream" changes from new ncurses releases, should it be necessary (I'm thinking for example bug fixes to terminfo definitions).

I also strongly support the decision to get a completely custom terminfo that doesn't rely on any other terminfo that already exist. I believe in the past there have been quite a few issues related to terminfo and some patches only work with the correct terminfo installed (there was one issue with multi-selection in some new vim-ish text editor iirc).

I've tried to set this up in the past, had only very limited success though, even when completely copying the xterm-256color terminfo I wasn't able to get the alacritty terminfo to work properly, maybe you can help out there @dnkl.

Also one case where I know that a custom terminfo would help is the cursor in neovim. When leaving neovim with custom cursors for insert/replace/normal enabled, the cursor is not automatically reset to the default cursor in xterm-256color since xterm doesn't support the escape sequence to reset the cursor shape to the default cursor. So going with a custom terminfo would allow me to potentially send a PR and get this working for Alacritty (and primarily myself :D).
Yeah that's probably a good idea!

issue.title: Create a standalone terminfo definition
issue.body:
In #1485, it was suggested that the current alacritty terminfo definition, which is based around the system's `xterm-256color` definition, be replaced with a custom definition without any system dependencies. I.e. make it completely standalone.

For a complete background, see the following comments:

* https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1485#issuecomment-409659033
* https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1485#issuecomment-409673655
* https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1485#issuecomment-409719745

The idea would be to start out with an xterm clone. That way, there will be no functional differences from the current definition.

body:
Unless someone else has already started working on this, I might take a stab at it after finishing #1491.

I've never done anything in rust before, but this looks like a fairly easy thing to implement.
